bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The apprenticing of African American minor children was done in pursuant of a circular letter issued by the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands dated October 4, 1865.

Amelia County was named for Amelia Sophia Eleanora, daughter of King George II. It was formed from Prince George and Brunswick Counties by an act passed in 1734 to take effect on 25 March 1735. The county court first met on 9 May 1735. The county seat is Amelia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Amelia County (Va.) Freedmen's Bureau Apprenticeship Indentures, 1868, record the binding of African American minor children to individuals for the purpose of learning a trade. Both are contractual agreements between the apprentice's master and agents of the Freedmen's Bureau. They stipulate the amount the master agreed to pay to the Freedmen's Bureau in exchange for an African American child to be bound to him or her by the Freedmen's Bureau; length of apprenticeship; and a statement of the obligations and responsibilities of each party. Information found in the apprenticeship indentures include names of masters and Freedmen's Bureau agents, bond amount, date of indenture, names and age of African American apprentice, and name of trade.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronological by date indenture was recorded.
